transcript.content: Intro
The Ricky Gervais Show on Guardian Unlimited.

You're listening to Ricky Gervais, with me Stephen Merchant and Karl Pilkington. Now you probably know me from such works as the Office and Extras, Stephen being my co-writer and co-director on those things. For those people who not so aware of Karl Pilkington: He was our producer, sort of given to us when we first started on XFM. And you're thinking, well, why are we doing a podcast? Why are we doing a podcast for-- For no money?
Is there no money?
No. It's free innit? It's free download. But this is what I'm here to answer. It's because I like to be in a room with Karl Pilkington. You know, like some people go and help sort of chimps.
(laughs) Do they?
Yeah.
Well, they go to the jungles and things, sure.
And they'll help out little sort of endangered species.
Dian Fossey or whatever.
Exactly, yeah.
You're very much the Dian Fossey of the Manchester scene.
Of the- of the... Little bald manc world. And Karl Pilkington is, is an ongoing experiment for me because I've seen him blossom from an idiot into an imbecile.
Steve laughs

And I want to see it through- Look at the way he's looking at us through the glass! Look at that! He's got a perfectly round head. And that's why I'm doing this podcast, or Bodcast, as I'm going to call it in his honor. Little round headed bod-type freak.
If you're not familiar with Bod, we can maybe put up a picture of Bod, the popular cartoon kids character.
Go to rickygervais.com and you will see a picture of Karl and a picture of Bod.
And you draw your own conclusions as to the likeness.
Karl, what do you think about all this?
That's alright.
You excited by this new technology?
What, podcasts?
Yeah, exactly.
Um, it's just, I mean, we are living in that sort of era now, aren't we, that you need to be able to listen to stuff on demand when you want it and stuff.
I know you're not a fan of the iPod in general, are you? Or any of the mp3 things. You're concerned?
I'm warming to it... But-
This is what's amazing about Karl, even though he's talking about things like mp3 players, computers, iPods, he sounds like he was found in a glacier and thawed out.
Steve laughs
Do you know what I mean? Sort of taught to speak.
We're a couple of high school guys who find him and we're trying to ingratiate him in the gang, trying to pass him off of someone from the modern day.

No no. But my thing with. With ipods is now, do we need them? Do you know what I mean? We're living in that era now where we have invented most of the stuff that we need, and now we're just messing about.
They said that in 1900! Someone actually said, "Everything that's to be invented has already been invented." They said that in 1900. And how wrong were they?
No, but what came out, at what point-- What was invented in that year? Where they went, right, that's it now.
Well hold on
What did they invent in 1900 that, that made them go "We've done it all now."
Well, just think! Think a little bit. Right? The 20th century. Think what happened in the 20th century.
Go on.
Well... Cars. Planes.
Yeah, but is that a good thing, planes and that? Do you need to. Do you need a plane? Really? Wouldn't have been better if we all stuck where we should be instead of traveling about?
Why?
War. Well, look, wars, war's happening, isn't it? Because everyone's saying, well, now we can fly, we'll go over there.
So there were no wars prior to the invention of the airplane?
Not like. Not like there is today.
Right.

But what I'm saying is the more- the world's got smaller innit?. Everyone's saying that. Right. You know, the way I was saying to you the other day, you know, we now go to places where we shouldn't go. People go on holiday to places where you've got of an injection before you go there. Yeah, forget it, then. That's a warning. Don't go there.
I am with you on that. I don't want to enter a country where I have to have an injection to stop me from dying while I'm in that country. I totally agree with you on that.

So what happened is, so they invented the plane and it's like, oh, let's go on holiday, and then they go, I'll die now. Oh, well, you've got to invent something. Let's invent an injection. And then it's like, right, well, what else do we need to go to that place? There's a lot of faffing.
Ricky and Steve laugh
So what I'm saying is.
Is that a place, A-lot-of-faffing?
What I'm saying is, you know, Steve's travelled more than I have. You've been to, like, dangerous places.
I've been to places where you need injections. Yep.
Yeah but why?

Because it's fascinating, isn't it? You know, don't you not believe in the idea of travel broadens the mind? You know, it makes you experience other ways of life, other ways of thinking. It just enriches you as a human being. That's the whole reason people go traveling.
But since the invention of the telly, you don't have to go that far to see.
You're absolutely right.
So there you go, then. The telly was the 20th century, wasn't it?
Yeah, it's pretty good.

So where would you. Where would you stop then? You'd stop making stuff now? Stop inventing stuff right now? Or do you think we could carry on for another five years, see what comes up and then just draw a line under it all.
Well, again, we're just messing about. And I-
But there's still things to do, isn't there? I mean, I know I could throw things up. You can always give an answer for it but, you know, a cure for cancer, a cure for AIDS.
Yeah, but should we, should we mess with that?
What do you mean?

Because there's too, there's too many people in the world as it isn't there? So that's a way of controlling it so that, you know, like, look at London, right? It's overpopulated. Rent keeps going up because there's more and more people surviving, right? You let them die, it's gonna even itself out. See, I was saying to someone the other day about maybe we should look at, if we're gonna invent something, right, forget, like, the traditional way of people having kids, right, the way they, you know, have it away in that.
No, what do you mean? What do you mean?

No. You know, like, the way that, you know, we have kids and stuff, if- it'd be good, if what happened was to control it is if man and woman, right, they sort of, they're born and that, they enjoy their life, they learn a lot, they live to be about 78, I think, by that point.
So specific
Yeah, 78, yeah.

No no no but by 78 I reckon you've sort of got to that point where you go, do you know what? I've done everything I'm gonna do. If you haven't bungee jumps by the time you're 78, you're not gonna do it. I mean, so it's kind of like.
No... Your hips come off.
You've done it all now. So I've had my innings.
Yeah.
And then you die, right? So say if everyone had that, they live to be 78, but then just as you die,
They give you the bumps.
You get, you have a little baby inside you, and as you die, your life carries on.
Sorry
How is this happening?
Sorry. Are you mental?
No no, but don't you think.
I mean, what? I've never heard such drivel.
You say, you're saying that, but if Newton said it. You'd go, hmm, interesting. That's what annoys me.
I love it.
Point is Karl he never would. He'd never say it. That's the point.
I don't understand what you're talking about there. What? How was it? How is there a little baby in a 78 year old?
No what I'm saying is, it's like an apple, where the apple grows and it's got its little baby pips in it, and the apple goes and the seeds are planted and a new one's born.
But that's what happened.
But that is what reproduction is.
Yeah, but I'm saying babies aren't being born left, right and center, it's, it's, it's controlled so that as someone dies, someone's born.
But Karl, stop. Whose responsibility is this?
Look if you don't want to do it then we won't do it.
Is it supposed to be nature? Has nature got to develop humans so that we act that way, so that we live that way? Or is it a scientific experiment?
I like, what I like, he said, he said to you then, he said, look if you don't want to do it, we don't need to do it. Like if you were up for it, we'll sort it out. We can do that.
We'll have a whip-round, so that we can do the research.

I just think at the end of the day, we've got to do something. And is anyone keeping an eye on this and looking at what we can do next to control the population thing? It does my head in that I've got to live in London for work and what have you, and there's loads of people here. And, you know, forget going out on a Saturday night, it's too busy. And you can't move and they keep. I mean, what annoys me about London is,
So your solution is that 78 year old women have little babies inside them and as they slip away into death, the little babies. And how is that baby then raised?
Who looks after the baby?
Who looks after the baby?
Cause it's a pretty good system, having a baby while you're young enough to look after that baby and make sure it lives to, you know, reproductive age itself.
I mean, that one, that's. That system's been working for years.
Nature sort of sorted it out. Natural selection and evolution sort of makes that a good model.
But wait a minute, nature. Pop that on hold because Karl Pilkington's got an idea.
Yeah
Yeah, it's just. It was just. That's what it was, just an idea.
Yeah, well, it was, you know, it was nonsense.
It was one of the worst ideas, I mean, it was the ramblings of. It was the ramblings of someone you'd find by themselves in a hospital eating flies.

Yeah. This is the sort of thing you find when, uh, if they find, uh, maybe a pamphlet or a booklet written by a psychopath, you know, someone just before they went on a rampage and then turned the gun on themselves, they go through their possessions and they find a book and it's got weird drawings. Women with knives in their face,
Yeah.
And this kind of gobbledygook.
In fact, I saw, I saw a similar sort of theory written out on a wall. But it was written in shit.
Exactly. Yeah.

No, all I'm, all I'm saying is I think it's, you know, when people die normally everyone's fed up about it, aren't they, and a bit down. But if, when you, if, when you pass away, you go, aww we're gonna miss Gladys or whatever, but then there's this new life brought in. It's almost like a bad news, good news.

You're talking about it like someone could pick this idea up and run with it. Like you've given them enough information to do it. How is this possible? Where does she get the baby from? Why does it grow? Why grow it in Gladys' belly? Why not have it in a drawer ready to go? Just add water. I mean--
Who looks after son of Gladys?!
There is no theory here! There's no- It's the ramblings of a mad man!
What I'm saying is, though, the body's always changing innit? From caveman to now or whatever.
(laughs) In some cases!
And they're always finding out more and more. Like I read the other day about how they saying, you know, like, they say people have six senses?
Yeah.
There's loads more than that.
Ricky laughs
Right? And there's this one-
Show me that you've got one!
No, right- And there's this one that's knocking about.
Go on.
That-- what it is. Say if I'm in a pub, right, and I'm just doing a crossword or whatever.
Unlikely, but go on.
And there's some woman who's walked in, right, and she's staring at me.
Yeah.
I know she's looking at me and I look up and I look around, she's looking at me.
Right.
And they're saying that's a new sense, that they found out from, like, you know, doing tests and what have you.
Yeah, it's rubbish.
And they say that's been around, since like, man and dinosaur was knocking about.
But it could be, it could be, you know, peripheral vision. It could be a footstep stopped, and usually when someone's footsteps stop there, they've stopped...
No, they've explained it!
I think it's safe to assume that, you know that with your perfectly round head, people are always stopping and looking.
No no, but they explained it.
You just know that they're probably going to be someone there, if you look round.
They said it's from the time when like caveman was like wandering about and he'd go, hang on a minute, and he'd look around, there's a dinosaur there, or whatever, and he'd leg it.

Right, this is nonsense! One: I hate when people are using the term "When caveman was wandering around." Caveman and dinosaurs?? Oh, they used to live together, yeah! Oh, that's the same era! Yeah. What have you been watching? Raquel Welch?!
What do you mean?
Well, what do you mean caveman wandering, knocking around with a dinosaur?
You know, the Flintstones is only partly based on fact?
Ricky laughs
Dinosaurs and man did not coexist! The dinosaurs had long gone before man arrived. Extinct. Kaput.
Hmmm.
What, you don't believe us?
You don't beleive it, cause you've seen-
Because you saw that film where they took pictures of lizards and magnified them and put them next to men in film so they look like they were fighting.
Yeah.
No, but why, why couldn't that have happened?
What is the film with Raquel Welch? 'A Million Years BC'.
'A Million Years BC' or something?
'A Million Years BC'. Brilliant.
Yeah
Yeah.
No, no, but--
She had a sort of woolly mammoth bikini. Fact.
But why, why wasn't the dinosaurs back then just like how we have dogs now in a way.
He's watching the Flintstones!
He's watching the Flintstones.
He's thinking of the Flintstones. That's what he's thinking.
When he puts out the saber-toothed tiger.
Yeah, yeah. And he mixes his concrete in a pelican.
Both laugh
I just think that, there must have been a crossover point.
Why? Why'd you say that? Why do you think there must have been a crossover point?
There must have been!
Because if nothing was knocking about at any point, how did anything carry on?
I know, exactly. Why didn't Hitler meet Nero? It's weird, isn't it? There must have been a crossover. They must have met somewhere. They must have met at a party somewhere.
They mix in similar circles.
Yeah, well, I mean, are you, are you telling me that Ken Dodd has never met Genghis Khan? They must have bumped into. I can't believe it.
Forget it.
Oh, you're listening to Ricky Gervais with Stephen Merchant and Karl Pilkington. Coming up after the ads, Monkey News.
What ads?
No ads, no?
No, we're not, there's nothing here. There's no records. We just got to keep on talking. Which is not-

We could do our own ads. Okay, bring tea for the tiller man, steak for the sun. Out now to own on DVD, Ricky Gervais's and Steve Merchant's Award-winning Extras with Ross Kemp. "Oh, Zippy!" with Les Dennis. Put your arse away, Les. I don't really know! And Kate Winslet. "Oh, this nun outfit mess makes me talk dirty." Out now on DVD, Extras.

Did you like Flanimals, the Ricky Gervais book for kids with pictures of made up creatures in, of different colours? Well, if you did, there's more of them now in the new book More Flanimals, which is also by Ricky Gervais. Drawings by his mate. Out now.
The Ricky Gervais Show on Guardian Unlimited.
You're listening to Ricky Gervais with Steve Merchant and Karl Pilkington.
Alright.
Well, now time for our regular features, Monkey News.
Do the jingle.
Ooh, chimpanzee that! Monkey News.
Right, what we're doing here is, right, is just giving you a bit of monkey news that's, that's gone on. Right. Where a monkey's been involved in it. Good little story and that.
Yeah.

Are you familiar with the one that went into space? The first, the first sort of thing they ever sent up there, before man did it and all that. You see, this is what annoys me with it, really. Armstrong gets all the, all the glory. But do you know who went up there before? Before him?
A monkey.
Yeah.
Yeah.
A dog went up first.
But what was the monkey called?
I don't know.
No, sure. Okay. So it's not the most informed news bulletin.
The dog was called Laika.
Was it?

Yeah. They couldn't get it back, though. They sent out there, did a few tests and stuff and they couldn't get it back. They weren't, they weren't prepared to bring the capsule back yet. Brilliant. We could all do that.
So is that, is that a, you know, is that a good mission?

Well, I just think it was seeing, what if it, if the mission itself killed it? But they didn't have the technology, because of course it couldn't, it couldn't fly the capsule back, which it has to be manned to bring.

Well, this, this was, this was the next one up then. Right. So the dog must have gone first. And then we went, right. We made an error there. Right. Get the monkey in. And what happened is they taught it what buttons to hit at the time it needed to hit them. And, and the way they did this was like give it bananas. It was like hit the red button and it hit the red button. They'd give it a banana.
Right.

And they go, right, reverse is the green one, hit the green one. And then they do that and go, there's a banana. And then they go, right, hit reverse and it'd go. And get a banana. Hit the red. So it was taking commands on like, headphones.
Right but how are they giving it the banana?
Is that how you learnt to do radio?
How are they giving it the banana?
What do you mean? No, this is before it went. You wouldn't just go and put a monkey in it and go, there you go. Get on with it. They sort of put him in one of them capsules that you get.
Yeah.
And they were on headphones.
I don't believe this happened.
Well, I'm telling you the story now, so the monkey's sat-
I don't think they trained it to do anything, I think they sent it up there and they put electrodes coming out of it to see what it
No, there wasn't any of that. They did a thing like they do. Like they can with animals. If you give something, you know, like a treat, you can teach how to do it. It's just like a dog in it.
It's called Pavlovian conditioning. However, that was to see if it would salivate or go over to a particular corner. Not if it could control a spacecraft.

Next one up. It's the next one up. As far as the monkey's- the monkey's not sat there going, oh, I'm a bit under pressure here it's a rocket. All that's knowing is, I'm getting a banana if I hit that button, that's all the monkeys thinking about.
They wouldn't put billions of space dollars...
How can they be sure that it's going to press the button at the right moment?
Because it's got headphones on.
Ricky laughs
They're telling it, they're not just-
Like you have now!
It's not like Willy nilly. It's not just like, pop it in there
Willy Nilly, who is that?
What's to stop it from just hitting it any old time? Because it's a monkey and it's not a human.
Because he's trained now.
Oh, it's trained, it's fully trained yeah, go on.
But anyway, so listen, so what happened is anyway
This is absolute rubbish.
They pop the monkey in there, he's got his headphones on, they're going "Right hit the green one." And I think there's something there that a little banana comes out to keep the same-
No, you're making this up.
I'm not. It's the same-
There's no way that they made a- a- a spacecraft that had banana dispenser. There's no way in this world that they made a spacecraft that could go into outer space. Right-
So what-? So- So you're..? Hmm...
That's manned by a monkey with a banana dispenser.
So you're saying that it's easy to send something up to space, but you don't believe there's a little banana machine.
Ricky laughs
Right okay, so in your world, in your world there's this, there's a monkey and it's been conditioned and there's a little monkey dispenser- Monkey, uh, sorry a monkey dispenser?

Banana. Yeah a little banana dispenser, right? So it comes to the launch day. Monkey's, monkey's sat in there. Everyone's ready, bananas are stocked up and all the rest of it. They go, "Right, hit the green button," [Rocket noises] And the rocket goes off and what have you.
No! They would not make the monkey launch the rocket. Karl, you are, you are living in a cartoon world.
So the rocket goes off, right?
[laughing] This is absolute bollocks!
It's all going well
You are, you are, I mean, I don't know where you get it-
It's all- It's going well.
It's not going well! There's no way a monkey launched a rocket. There is no way a monkey launched a rocket, you idiot!
So it's all going on, so they're going "Hit the left button" and it goes a little bit left
The left button! Oh well-known spacecraft command! This is Houston, hit the left button. Oh, brilliant. This is what happened in Appollo 13. Hit the left button.
So, it goes left, yeah, it goes left.
So it goes left. And it's, it's going away-
Left!
Yeah.
No, the moon! You're going right!
So it goes, it goes for the moon and everything, everything's going well. They get up there, it does, whatever it does. "Hit reverse," it comes back.
[laughing] Hit reverse!
You are honestly, you are brain dead. So it's not one of the most stupid people- that I would rather have the monkey drive me home than you.
So the thing is. So it lands back, does a good job and everything, it gets out.
It's sick of bananas.
This is where. This is where it turns a bit sad, because after it done that mission, right, because it happened and it was all safe and everything, the next one would have been to send man,
Right...
So the monkey enjoyed and it was like, well, I want to do it again, right? But they were like...
Sorry, how did they know that? How did they know?
Just the way it looked and what have you.
Ricky laughs
Fuck off! Just the way it looked! You are a maniac.
So the thing is, though, right? So after it had done that, it was on such a high, right? It could never get that high again. There's nothing. There was nothing that it could do.
Went on tour, did it?
It sort of ended up killing itself. Because it could never, never get that buzz that it got.
That was absolute bollocks. None of that is true. Except they sent a monkey into space. And I'll check that. Absolute drivel.
So in your mind, it committed suicide. It went on a crazy bender. Drinking, drugs and women. And then...
It does happen. You hear about it, right?
And it was found in a motel room.
Do right you don't believe in- scary stuff. Just like, you know, ghosts.
I believe in scary stuff, I don't believe in things that are totally illogical.
Ghosts and that.
Ghosts
Vampires?
No. Anything made up by man.
Well, there was something in the paper the other day about a vampire. Oh, they found one. They dug something up.
It was in the paper. It's true then.
It's definitely true.
It's definitely true then.
But we'll leave that cuz you're just gonna do that so it doesn't matter.
No come on.
Come on, quickly tell us you found...
It's just that they found. They found a body in a coffin with a bit of wood through its heart and a knife in its mouth. But if you don't believe it.
Vampire pirate.
But that's definitely proof of a vampire then. Of course, and not some grotesque murder. That's definitely proof
If it was found.
If it was, if it wasn't- one, if it wasn't made up. Two...
Hang on a minute.
As far as I'm aware that, Rick, when you put the thing through the heart, they just turn into dust.
And also all that. All their victims get their own lives back.

Yeah, it was the second bit. Somebody dug it up, got the heart, blended it, burnt it, pop it, popped it in some water, drank it and they're in prison now. Now if it wasn't dodgy stuff, why they in prison?
They're mental. Because they dug up a body, liquidized its heart, burnt it and drank it. That's why they're in prison.
There's your answer.
But anyway, that is what I'm talking about. Right, but I met. I met Derek Acorah the other week.
Oh, yeah.
Right,
Now, who's he? Which one's he? Is he a medium? He can contact the dead, is that right?
He just chats to them and that. Passes messages on.
Nice of him.

So I said, oh, tell us sommat a bit weird and that. So he said, what do you know? I said, just, just sommat weird. So he goes all right then. He said, here's one for you, right? And he said there's this pub out in the country. And uh he said there's this mug. Do you know those old mugs that they have where they used to, they used to like leave their own cup, knocking about.
Oh, yeah, yeah, yeah.
Tankard thing.
Yeah.
So. So there was, there was one of them mugs in there, right? And everybody-
Tankard, let's use tankard if we've established what it is
Yeah
Because you're the only mug in this story, believing it all.
High five. Great.
So this tankard's knocking about, right? And everyone who's running the pub keeps going, oh, I wish to stop leaving this tankard about, right, and they pick it up.
It must be a pain having a tiny, small tankard in a pub. That must be a real grind.
So, so every time they sort of picked it up and went, we'll have to wash that. And they popped it on a different sideboard. Next thing you know, that person who's touched it died. Right.
Sure.
So-
They must have been getting through bar staff.
So they got. So they kept getting in new staff and that and they went: What's the connection here?
What's the connection here?
Ooh God.
So anyway so they-
Call Australia, we've run out!
So they. So they- they sort of. Someone notices and they go, you know, it's a bit weird. It's that cup, right? So they get-
Tankard.
They, they get so there's that it's that tankard and that. So um, they get a vicar in.
Of course they do.

And they go, look, erm, there's a lot of weird stuff going on here. This, this, this tankard, every time someone touches it, they die. So he said, leave it with me. He gets his special water out and what have you. He comes around, does a little prayer, sprinkles it. He goes, right, not a problem. Don't worry about it. He picks it up, chucks it in the bin. Guess what?
What?
Dies in a crash on the way home because he picked it up.
What? But. But Karl, you're telling me this like it's fact, and I meant to go that's amazing.
Derek Acorah. He told me.
Karl. I have. I have. I have no opinion of that story, other than I'm pretty sure there was absolutely no connection between touching the tankard and him dying. That's all I'm sure of.
It's not just him, though, is it? It's-

I-I'm-I-I'm-I. You know, I'm not gonna even contest the chain of events. All I'm saying is there is no connection. There is no connection possible, because I believe in logic and the laws of the universe. So when you. When you're telling me miracles and strange things outside coincidence, you may as well be telling me about the tooth fairy in the Easter bunny, because they're equal to me. It's ludicrous. It's absolutely ludicrous.
So what- what would it take, though, for you to go, ooh, I'm actually a believer now?

But, but what you're saying is you're- I can't answer that question because I'd have to base my beliefs on some of your premises, which I can't do. It's like you saying, but what if you found out that two and two equaled five? I can't. It's a necessary truth that it doesn't. I'd have to. I'd have to go back and fundamentally disagree with what I think twoism is, twoness, and fiveness.
You've never been in a situation, though, where you've gone, this room feels a bit weird, 'cause there's sommat. Do you know I mean, could be sommat knocking about or...
But that's, that's, that's a different question. I-I could go into a really rough looking pub and think, this, this isn't good, because it's, it's, based on induction, then.
I mean. I mean, like, you know, if you've been to Cornwall on holiday and stayed somewhere and you've gone, you know what? Sure summat's died in here.
I'm sure summat's died everywhere.
Yeah, but what I mean, you never pick up a vibe of- Like, I-I, I've got a mate, right, who, uhh he's, he's living in this big stately home, right, and what it is-
Why is he living there?
He's paying hundred pounds a month, right? And it's almost like he's being a security man.
Ah, right.
But He's not, he's not. He doesn't sit at the door with a hat on and everything. He just goes about his life, but he bases most of his work in this stately home.
So what is it? Like a, like a-
Like a housekeeper? Like he's sort of house sitting?
A little bit. Yeah. I mean, it's mass. It's bigger than Buckingham palace, this place. Right?
So what is it? A billionaire that's gone away or something?
I think it's some sort of, uhh. I think he said something about a viscount or summat, right? He said it's. He owns this place, he's living in America. This place he owns, but it's fallen to bits.
Wow.

And he's worried that people are gonna go in there and squat and what have you. So he said to me mate, you know, there was an advert in the paper, he don't know him, advert in the paper saying, do you want to live in a big house? 100 quid or whatever. And uhh, he went and had a look, right? And he's living in there now, he pays 100 pounds a month. There's about 80 rooms.
Jee...

And uhh, it's this big stately house and what have you. And I went, I went down there, he said, oh, come down, have a look, right? And from outside you go, aw, this is brilliant. It's like something out of, you know, like the Manor Born or something. You go, this is, this is impressive. But then when you get in, it's like, it's a wreck.
It's just falling apart because they can't afford...
Well, it's just been left. No one's, No one's doing any vacin' up or anything. There's like rat poison everywhere. Emm, like windows are smashed, doors kicked in.
That's a real shame. Why is it-
I don't think he's doing his job, is he?
Is it because it. Because it would cost like millions to do up or something?
Apparently it'd be like, I think they're going to have it done up but it's going to cost like 80 million. Right. So anyway, so.
That's a big house.
That's a big house

So, we get, we go to the pub and what have you. I've got like a little torch and umm, we're wandering around looking in all these different rooms, right? And I'm asking him what's...what, why's, wh-how's it got in this state? You know, I mean if someone's had it, why have they let it get to this state? And he was saying how, you know, it was like a mental home at one point and um, it was like a drug thing as well, people who had had problems with drugs, they popped him out there, cuz it's in the middle of nowhere. Do you know, I mean if you, if you needed drugs or anything, forget it, it's not gonna happen. Y'know what i mean? So, so that's, straight away. Do you know, like have you ever been in a hospital when it's been shut down or a school when there's no kids in it and there's that sort of bad atmosphere of like weirdness?
Yeah.
Right
For the sake of argument, you know
Yeah (laughs)

So, so we're wandering about and I say, oh ee-ar, what's in this room, right? And we go in, and all the floors are like a wreck and rotten and stuff. And I looked at the wall and there was like a little piece of paper, stuck on the wall.
Oh.
Right. And I said, what's this here? So I wandered over, right? Got right up close to it and somebody had wroted.
Ricky and Steve laugh
Somebody had wroted?!
No, some-
Somebody had wroted...
In Jackanory. Okay, right, yeah, go on. Sorry.
So there's a little sign there, right. And I go up to it and it says flies, right? With an arrow. Flies, like flies this way.
Yeah.
I think "that's a bit weird." So I follow the arrow, right? Which goes to this corner where there's a shelf. About 3000 dead flies on it.
Oh my God.
Condom stuck on the top.
*Laughing*
That's weird, innit?
That is weird.

That is weird, right. So I'm looking at that and there's loads of stuff on the floor and that. Bits of paper picked up this bit of paper, right? And it had like in Biro and that. It looked really old, like it been there years. And it had something like need nappies, dummy, right?  Blankets, blah, blah. All this like all stuff for, right?. And I turned it over, right, and it said, none of this now needed. Baby dead.
Oh God *laughing*
Right?
Now, that's weird, innit? Now that's what I'm talking about. When you get a bad vibe, you go, that's. That's who's been in here.
So I don't actually understand what point you're trying to make, Karl.
Just because who's written that? Who's been in that room? Who's been in that state? And then straight away your mind starts going, "oh, I'm getting bad vibes in here"
But, Karl, didn't you just tell us that it was once occupied by drug addicts and mentals, to use your word
Yeah

So don't, haven't you put two and two together and thought that was probably who wrote it. That doesn't mean it's paranormal or ghostly. You walk into a building, it's a big, terrifying, empty house. It's terrifying in as much as it's cold and dark and drafty and a little bit spooky in this sort of illustrative sense.
And insecure.
Yeah. You're a bit nervous because you and, you know, it's got this sort of, it's got its bad vibe is just based on the fact that
Your mate's in charge.

Yeah, that's terrifying. I mean, yeah. So it's like saying, are we scared of the dark? Yes, it's. I understand why people are scared of the dark. I'm a little bit scared of the dark.  You're walking along
Because you don't know what's in it.

Yeah, you don't know what's in the darkness. That's why we'll get nervous. It doesn't mean you have to make the leap then that you've got some paranormal sense. "Oh, my God. I'm Karl Pilkington. And hang on. Just like Derek Acorah, I have sensed something strange and evil in this room. Wait a minute. There's some flies and a condom. I was right all along."
That is weird.
Flies and a johnny equals badness.
The flies and the condom was weird enough
It's weird, I don't know that it's
But, but, but the note. The note. I just think of his face when he saw that. Reading it by torchlight. He must have been terrified.
It's a bit, it's a bit odd, innit?
Thank you very much indeed for listening. If you'd like to get in touch with us, either myself or Ricky, or you've got something to send to Karl, then you can email us at podcast@rickygervais.com

I'd just like to say thank you to both the Guardian for sponsoring this and Positive Internet for hosting this podcast. Both great. The guys at positive Internet know exactly what they're doing. They're my kind of people, as is the Guardian.
Sorry, I just. You weren't contractually obliged to say that, were you? Just saying.
No, it's what I think. Just what I think.
Right. It's just I've not heard you mention either of them before in that way. Just sounded.
Oh, you're joking. I- I both love the Guardian and Positive Internet. Great guys.
Okay, that's just the way you feel it's not... yep.

trivia.description: Dian Fossey was an American primatologist and conservationist known for undertaking an extensive study of mountain gorilla groups
'Bod' is a British children's cutout animated cartoon series, first shown on BBC1 in 1975.
